items.title: CSL and Wisetech shares smashed & Australia's ASEAN opportuntties
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Australia's Special Envoy to Southeast Asia Nicholas Moore to find out how regional leaders feel about doing business with Australians as he attends the ASEAN summit; plus Michael Jenneke from UBS Management takes a look at the day's sharemarket action as CSL and Wisetech shares crash.

items.title: Kidney disease drug added to PBS, helping 65,000 Australians
items.summary: The federal government will add a medicine for chronic kidney disease into the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. More than 65.000 Australians are expected to benefit from the cheaper access to Jardiance , also known as Empagliflozin.

items.title: States face fresh scrutiny in youth justice shake-up after 'deeply disturbing' evidence
items.summary: Inquiry to examine if children's rights are violated in custody and if Australia is upholding its international obligations.

items.title: 'I did it': Accused assassin admits murdering former Japanese PM Shinzo Abe
items.summary: Tetsuya Yamagami, 45, was arrested at the scene of the shooting in July 2022 after allegedly firing at Shinzo Abe with a homemade gun.

items.title: Jamaica braces for Hurricane Melissa, strongest storm in a century
items.summary: Hurricane Melissa, a rare and powerful Category Five storm, is bearing down on Jamaica, threatening to be the island’s worst hurricane in more than a century. With winds near 280 kilometres an hour and up to a metre of rain forecast, the storm could cause catastrophic flooding. Authorities warn that the entire island is at risk, with Cuba and the Bahamas also in Melissa’s path later this week.

items.title: A prisoner, an exile or a politician: Who do Palestinians want as their future president?
items.summary: Three contenders to lead a future Palestinian state have emerged, but experts say only one is a viable option for Gaza and the West Bank.

items.title: Environmental law overhaul sparks political storm in Canberra
items.summary: The long-awaited overhaul of Australia’s national environmental law is set to ignite Parliament this week, as the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act (EPBC) faces its first major reform in twenty-six years. This second attempt at a package, featuring an independent EPA and a new National Interest power, has already generated a political firestorm. The Opposition is demanding the bill be split, while the Greens warn the entire package is "riddled with loopholes."

items.title: Are you owed a slice of Australia's unclaimed billions? Here's how to find out
items.summary: From forgotten super to old bank accounts, billions in unclaimed money is waiting to be claimed.

items.title: Town mourns after two killed in underground mine explosion in far western NSW
items.summary: A man and a young woman have been killed in a mine explosion near the outback town of Cobar in far western New South Wales. An investigation is underway into the cause of the underground blast, which has devastated the local community. Political leaders and mining unions say the tragedy highlights the urgent need to strengthen workplace safety in Australia’s mining industry.

items.title: NZYQ deportees arrive in Nauru | Evening News Bulletin 28 October 2025
items.summary: Nauru receives the first group of deportees from Australia under a deal that is expected to last 30 years; a court ruling overturns the Queensland government's ban on puberty blockers for transgender adolescents; and in basketball, Australian Josh Giddey plays a starring role in Chicago's win over Atlanta.

items.title: Queensland reinstates puberty blocker ban hours after state's top court overturns it
items.summary: Despite a court ruling overturning the ban, Queensland’s health minister has issued a new directive blocking puberty blockers for transgender youth.

items.title: Burke confirms first cohort of NZYQ deportees in Nauru
items.summary: The first cohort of NZYQ deportees has arrived in Nauru, under a removal pathway expected to cost taxpayers $2.5 billion.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 28 October 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Thousands flee humanitarian disaster as paramilitary group seizes last Sudan army base
items.summary: Sudan’s civil war has entered a dangerous new phase as the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) seize the army’s last major base in Darfur. The fall of El-Fasher has sparked a humanitarian crisis, with thousands fleeing and aid groups warning of ethnic violence and starvation.

items.title: Investigation underway into deadly NSW mine explosion | Midday News Bulletin 28 October 2025
items.summary: An investigation underway into a mine blast that has killed two workers; Western Australia to apologise for the 1834 Pinjarra massacre; and in sport, speculation that Australian coach Ange Postecoglou could return to Celtic.

items.title: Nationals senator says TikTok bullied his office amid new teen social media ban details
items.summary: Meta, TikTok and Snapchat have confirmed they will all comply with the impending under-16s social media ban.

items.title: 'Voices are not being heard': Plea to Albanese over critical minerals deal
items.summary: These Australians say a visit from Prime Minister Anthony Albanese would send a "strong signal" to regional communities.

items.title: Outback town in 'complete and utter shock' after two killed in underground mine explosion
items.summary: The dead have not yet been formally identified, but they are believed to be a woman in her 20s and a man in his 60s, who had both been living in Cobar.

items.title: UN warns of ethnically motivated 'atrocities' in Sudan's al-Fashir
items.summary: The advance by the Rapid Support Forces has raised fears of reprisals against the estimated 250,000 people remaining in al-Fashir.

items.title: UN warns of ethnically motivated 'atrocities' in Sudan's al-Fashir
items.summary: The advance by the Rapid Support Forces has raised fears of reprisals against the estimated 250,000 people remaining in al-Fashir.

items.summary: A category 5 hurricane hits Jamaica; calls for a senate inquiry after September's Triple Zero outage; Macarthur F-C brush off illness to rise from the bottom of the table.

items.title: Trump leaves door open for unconstitutional third term: 'I would love to do it'
items.summary: Steve Bannon, the pro-Trump podcaster and former White House chief strategist, has said there was a plan to circumvent the US 22nd amendment.

items.title: Jamaica braces for devastation as category 5 Hurricane Melissa closes in
items.summary: Authorities say the slow-moving hurricane could unleash days of catastrophic weather across the Caribbean, which has already killed seven people.

items.title: Universities, Israel, and weapons companies: National student vote takes on hot-button issue
items.summary: Students have long led anti-war movements in Australia. The first national vote in 50 years has taken on the question of weapons company links.

items.title: Osamah is the first to arrive in Australia via this new visa pathway. His long 'limbo' is over
items.summary: The 24-year-old, originally from Yemen, is one of just 20 refugees due to come to Australia as part of this pilot program.

items.title: PKK withdrawing fighters from Turkiye after decades-long insurgency
items.summary: The Kurdistan Workers' Party, otherwise known as the P-K-K, has announced it will withdraw its fighters from Turkiye after a decades-long insurgency. While the move has been welcomed by many, the P-K-K says it now wants to see Turkiye's government act in good faith to protect Kurdish rights and allow the group to enter mainstream politics.

items.title: How to check if you're eligible to claim part of this $50m payout from Facebook
items.summary: The landmark settlement arose from Meta's involvement in the Cambridge Analytica scandal.

items.title: US China optimism boosts ASX ahead of global rate decisions
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Elio D'Amato from EnviroInvest about why investors are increasingly optimistic of a US China trade deal ahead of leadership talks, as some global central banks prepare to cut interest rates this week.

items.title: 'Testament to the spirit of our people': Timor Leste formally admitted to Southeast Asian bloc
items.summary: Timor-Leste has officially joined ASEAN as its 11th member state – an achievement more than a decade in the making. The moment marks both a diplomatic triumph and a new chapter for the young nation forged from decades of struggle.

items.title: Trump ally Milei scores stunning election win, vows more reforms in Argentina
items.summary: The elections were the first test for Milei since he won office in 2023 on a promise to revive the economy through a series of reforms.

items.title: 'Fearsome arsenal': Russia sends clear message to the world with nuclear tests, experts say
items.summary: Russia appears to ramp up its military presence in the Arctic, but experts say its actions could have unintended consequences.

items.title: PM reports "positive" meeting with Chinese Premier | Evening News Bulletin 27 October 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, the Prime Minister raises concerns over a recent military incident, in a meeting with China's premier, the government rules out giving tech companies free reign to mine content for AI models. And in golf, Australia beats the US to take out the international crown teams' event in South Korea.

items.title: Copyright laws to protect creatives from AI data mining
items.summary: The Albanese government has handed Australian artists a major victory by definitively ruling out a controversial exemption that would have allowed tech companies free rein to mine creative work to train AI models. This decision, which was immediately praised as a "critical step in the right direction" by the creative sector, now paves the way for the Copyright and AI Reference Group to convene and determine the next steps for modernising Australia's copyright laws.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 27 October 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: 'Straight guy' Albanese raised concern with Chinese leader, amid 'upward momentum'
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has met with Chinese Premier Li Qiang while in Kuala Lumpur for the ASEAN summit.

items.title: Trump, trade and security: ASEAN Summit gets underway in Malaysia
items.summary: The 47th annual ASEAN summit is underway in Malaysia, with talks expected to focus on trade and regional security - with a dash of US President Donald Trump. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is also attending and says his focus for the trip will be Australian jobs and security.

items.title: 'Maddest idea': Watt rejects 'desperate' Coalition request, risking environmental bill
items.summary: Labor's overhaul of environmental protections is already at risk, with the Coalition demanding parts of the bill be delayed.

items.title: Australia acted on own intel, Burke says, as Israel names alleged Iranian attack plotter
items.summary: Israel says an Iranian commander was also the mastermind behind attacks in Greece and Germany.

items.title: Calls for support of environment law reforms | Midday News Bulletin 27 October 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, negotiations in parliament over a bill to reform Australia's environment laws, Microsoft is sued by Australia’s competition regulator. And in Formula One, Lando Norris reclaims leadership of the world championship from Oscar Piastri.

items.title: This contraceptive method will soon be much cheaper for Australians
items.summary: Australia has one of the lowest uptake rates in the developed world for long-acting contraceptives.

items.title: Government rules out changes to copyright law as creatives push for AI protections
items.summary: Attorney-General Michelle Rowland said the tech industry and creative sector must "come together".

items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese attends the 47th ASEAN summit; RSF forces claim they've captured the Sudanese army's El-Fashir headquarters; Samoa books their spot in rugby league's Pacific Cup final.

items.title: Japan calls on Australia to strengthen ties as Quad alliance strains under Trump
items.summary: Japan's newly elected Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi says she hopes Australia and Japan will deepen their cooperation.

items.title: I'm a member of the 'sandwich generation'. I scoff at the term
items.summary: I care for my elderly mother and two teenage sons, but to truly show up for them, I've had to learn how to care for myself too.

items.title: French police arrest two men over Louvre jewel heist
items.summary: The two suspects were known to the police for committing thefts, a source close to the case said.

items.title: 'Shadow fleet' still appearing in Australian supply chains despite sanctions, research finds
items.summary: US and EU sanctions on Russia's largest oil companies this week has left refineries in China and India assessing their implications. Some sell refined products to Australia. But will the latest measures be able to capture Russia's shadow fleet that exploit sanction loopholes? Exclusive data shared with SBS has shown vessels transporting Russian crude oil and previously sanctioned by the Federal government still appear in the supply chains of Australian companies.

items.title: Cambodia and Thailand sign peace deal alongside Trump
items.summary: A final comprehensive peace pact between the two Southeast Asian neighbours still remain outstanding.

items.title: Evening News Bulletin 26 October 2025
items.summary: US President Donald Trump says Cambodia-Thailand peace deal could save millions of lives, Government proposes first National Environment Protection Agency to keep businesses accountable, Liverpool lose 3-2 at Brentford, making it four league losses in a row.

items.title: Who gets to be called Aussie? Why these posters are causing another stir — 10 years on
items.summary: Artist Peter Drew is reinvigorating his conversation-starting artworks about what it really means to be Australian.

items.title: Man charged after Australian cricketers allegedly 'touched inappropriately' in India
items.summary: The players have been offered support, and are believed to be ready to continue playing in the tournament.

items.title: Midday News Bulletin 26 October 25
items.summary: Anthony Albanese will push for free trade at the upcoming ASEAN and APEC talks in Asia; two Australian women's cricket players allege assault, as a man is arrested in India; the Matildas beat Wales in a 2-1 victory in Cardiff, in star player Sam Kerr's long-awaited return to the team.

items.title: Labor moves to create Australia's first national environment watchdog
items.summary: The proposed environment protection agency is part of a raft of reforms to federal environmental laws.

items.title: 'I am not done': Kamala Harris leaves door open for another US presidential bid
items.summary: "I have lived my entire career a life of service, and it's in my bones," the former US vice-president says.

items.title: Trump hits Canada with 10 per cent tariff hike in retaliation for anti-tariff TV ad
items.summary: The Canadian province of Ontario's ad uses the words of Republican former US president Ronald Reagan to criticise tariffs.

items.title: How a literacy and numeracy program is helping adults open up career options
items.summary: One in five Australians, or around three-million adults, have low literacy or numeracy skills - and it can have a big impact on how people are able to engage in every day life. Programs are in place across the country to help people improve their skills and achieve their life goals. Including one in Tasmania, helping adults become work ready.

items.title: Are aliens from space waiting to invade? Probably not, say the scientists
items.summary: The prospect for an alien invasion of Earth has been flooding the Internet in recent weeks thanks to the object 3-I-ATLAS currently hurtling through our solar system which some have warned may be an alien spacecraft that can attack our planet. Spoiler alert - NASA says it isn't. But even so, the fears of alien invasion are nothing new: in the final years of the nineteenth century, in his novel War of the Worlds, British author H G Wells wrote that 'minds immeasurably greater than our own, across the gulf of space, made their plans against us'. So what is the likelihood of an alien invasion? In this edition of Weekend One on One, Jason Wright, professor of astronomy and astrophysics at Penn State University and director of the Penn State Extraterrestrial Intelligence Centre looks into whether it could happen here.

items.title: The 'horrendous' gamble of fast-tracking the Trump-Albanese critical minerals deal
items.summary: The $13 billion deal has been widely celebrated, but some warn "stark changes" pose a risk to the environment and food.

items.title: INTERVIEW: 'Deaths of Despair': the deadly dangers of homelessness
items.summary: New data shows Australians experiencing homelessness are more likely to die from overdose, suicide or coronary heart disease, with potentially nine avoidable deaths every day. Data from the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare has found that around 43,200 people with a history of homelessness died between 2012 and 2013 alone from these types of causes. The median age was 55 years, far lower than the Australian median life expectancy of 81.1 years for men and 85.1 years for women. For women, gendered violence remains a leading cause of homelessness across Australia, impacting almost 67,000 people every year. Kate Colvin is the CEO of Homelessness Australia and she's been talking to SBS's Cameron Carr.

items.title: Anthony Albanese and Donald Trump are on their way to Asia. Here's what's on their agendas
items.summary: The prime minister and US president will visit Malaysia and South Korea for regional summits.

items.title: Pannir couldn't speak to the media from death row. He wrote poetry instead
items.summary: Singapore has executed 14 prisoners this year. Among them was Pannir, hanged earlier this month for a first-time drug offence.

items.title: Revealed: Sanctioned Russian 'shadow' tankers in Australian oil product supply chains
items.summary: Data shows more than a third of oil tankers from Russia's 'shadow fleet' sanctioned in June are supplying Australian companies.

items.summary: Anthony Albanese joins Donald Trump and other leaders for the annual ASEAN summit; Israel launches air strikes in central Gaza, in defiance of the US brokered ceasefire; Virat Kohli and Rohit Sharma lead India to a nine-wicket victory over Australia in the third one-day international.

items.title: Rain, reflection and renewal: Uluru marks 40 years since historic handback
items.summary: Four decades after Uluru was returned to its traditional owners, the Anangu people are celebrating a moment that reshaped the nation.

items.summary: Donald Trump says he doesn’t forget when people “say bad” about him, despite earlier appearing to accept an apology from Kevin Rudd.

items.title: These furry housemates can test your patience. Here's how to make peace with them
items.summary: It's spring, which means your noisy upstairs neighbours might be getting a little more rowdy.

items.title: The Sydney brothers hoping to bring surf lifesaving back to war-torn Gaza
items.summary: A long-held dream to start Gaza's first surf club is still alive, despite the enclave's devastation.

items.title: Midday News Bulletin 25 October 2025
items.summary: Anthony Albanese heads to ASEAN and APEC summits for week of quiet diplomacy; ceremonies mark 40 years since Uluru and Kata Tjuta returned to Anangu Traditional Owners; Sam Kerr eager to lead Matildas again as she eyes Asian Cup glory.

items.title: The $27 million reason Aussie matcha fanatics could face a shake-up
items.summary: Australia's growing obsession with matcha is opening the door for a new player, as Japan faces supply shortages and rising prices.

items.title: US imposes sanctions on Colombian president Gustavo Petro as feud escalates
items.summary: The Trump administration has sharply escalated a feud over accusations Petro has failed to stop drugs from entering the US.

items.title: US imposes sanctions on Colombian president Gustavo Petro as feud escalates

items.title: Peanut butter loving babies are licking allergies, study suggests
items.summary: A decade after a landmark study proved that feeding peanut products to young babies could prevent them developing life-threatening allergies, a new US study has shown it's making a big difference in the real world. The study has found about 60,000 children in the United States have avoided developing peanut allergies after new guidance was issued in 2015 about when to introduce the allergen to youngsters.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Inside Sudan's deepening humanitarian crisis
items.summary: The civil war in Sudan has been raging for two and a half years and has generated arguably the largest humanitarian crisis on the planet. Often called the forgotten war, the conflict has torn apart the Northeast African country of 50 million people leaving around 12 million displaced from their homes and often with very little access to food, clean water and medicine. Reena Ghelani is the CEO of Plan International - one of the humanitarian organisations seeking to make a difference on the ground.

items.title: Traditional owners mark 40th anniversary of Uluru handback in London
items.summary: Anangu traditional owners have marked 40 years since Uluru Kata Tjuta National Park was handed back to their people. The handback was a landmark moment for Aboriginal land rights in Australia and a powerful recognition of the enduring connection between First Nations peoples and Country. The official celebrations have included a trip to London for a delegation of nine Anangu traditional owners, who met with High Commissioner to the UK Stephen Smith, and King Charles, as part of the official commemorations.

items.title: Why some Australians stand by the royal family despite the Prince Andrew scandal
items.summary: Polls show Australians have little sympathy for Prince Andrew — yet backing for the royal family and constitutional monarchy remains steady. Why?

items.title: The 'vicious cycle' that could see the most prescribed drugs in Australia become obsolete
items.summary: Common infections are becoming more resistant to treatment, and it's leaving experts worried for vulnerable groups.

items.title: Morning News Bulletin 25 October 2025
items.summary: New search launched for missing teen Colleen Walker-Craig; Greens accuse government of weakening environmental protections; Gold Coast's pursuit of Craig Bellamy as head coach for 2027 is over.

items.title: Spotlight on US, Australia inflation; super balances hit new record
items.summary: The ASX-200 has ended the week in the red, as investors await the outcome of Donald Trump’s much-anticipated meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the APEC Summit next week. Attention is also turning to the release of key September CPI data in the US, despite the government shutdown.

items.title: Families vow to fight on despite ex-soldier's acquittal over Bloody Sunday killings
items.summary: The only soldier ever prosecuted over a massacre of civilians in 1972 that became known as Bloody Sunday has been found not guilty of murder and attempted murder charges. The presiding judge at Belfast County Court has ruled that while he was satisfied the former paratrooper was among a group of soldiers who shot at civilians after a civil rights march, there was not enough evidence to convict him of the killings.

items.title: How does your balance compare? Australians reach a $172k super milestone
items.summary: There has also been a "historic" retirement shift, according to a peak body. Here's how much Australians have in their accounts.

items.title: Australia deploys ADF liaison to US-led Civil-Military Coordination Centre in Israel
items.summary: Australia is deploying one ADF liaison officer to a new US-led coordination centre in Israel to support the fragile Gaza ceasefire and President Trump's 20-point peace plan. However, a local analyst has heavily criticised the contribution as purely symbolic.

items.title: Canadian province will stop running anti-tariff ad that angered Trump, halted trade talks
items.summary: Ontario's premier said the ad would stop running after this weekend's baseball World Series games.

items.title: West Bank faces threat of annexation as Knesset vote condemned by US officials
items.summary: More aid is entering Gaza under a fragile ceasefire, but humanitarian agencies say it remains far from enough to meet the needs of its starving population. But discussions on how to achieve – and maintain – peace have coincided with Israel's Knesset narrowly advancing a bill to apply Israeli law to the occupied West Bank. It's being widely condemned as a preliminary step to approving total annexation.

items.summary: Thousands of Samsung users face paying for replacements after the government ruled telcos must fix faulty phones unable to call triple-zero.

items.title: New US, EU sanctions aim to pressure Russia towards ceasefire
items.summary: The United States has unveiled its most forceful move yet to pressure Russia into ending the war in Ukraine. President Donald Trump has announced broad sanctions on Russia’s two biggest oil giants, Rosneft and Lukoil. The measures mark a decisive shift in tone from the US, targeting the lifeblood of Russia’s economy in a bid to choke off Russia's Ukraine war funding

items.summary: A new taskforce based in Victoria will continue the search for alleged police killer Dezi Freeman.

items.title: AUKUS and an awkward moment: What it was like in the room for Albanese's 'dream run' with Trump
items.summary: It finally happened - Prime Minister Anthony Albanese met with US President Donald Trump. It took 10 months, and SBS Chief Political Report Anna Henderson breaks down how that benefited Albanese as he faced his biggest test on the international stage.

items.title: WFH rights & the RBA's take on critical minerals
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves takes a look at the day's market action and an RBA research report on critical minerals with Elizabeth Tian from Citi, plus Mahnaz Angury speaks with workplace law expert Giuseppe Carabetta from University of Technology Sydney about the impact of a recent work from home ruling in favour of a bank employee, to reject a request to return to the office.

items.title: Vladimir Putin says Russia will not bow to the pressure of US sanctions on oil giants
items.summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin also warned of an "overwhelming" response to any military strikes deep inside Russia.

items.summary: Indonesia says it won’t be sidelined from world sport after the IOC urged federations to stop hosting events there in response to its ban on Israeli gymnasts.

items.title: Escape. Hide. Tell. Staying safe in a terrorist attack
items.summary: Counter-terrorism police forces across Australia have launched a new campaign that aims to educate people about how to protect themselves in the event of an armed attack. Authorities say Australia is at risk from weapons attacks, especially in crowded places, while the country's terror threat level remains at probable.

items.title: Albo, Trump and the elephant in the room, Gaza ceasefire fractures & a very French heist
items.summary: In this episode: Behind the scenes of Prime Minister Anthony Albanese’s highly anticipated meeting with US President Donald Trump, while Ukraine’s leader Vlodymyr Zelenskyy walks away from the White House without his Tomahawk missiles. Plus, more threats to the Gaza ceasefire despite optimism from US Vice President JD Vance, the ‘high-stakes’ meeting between the Australian and Indonesian military chiefs, and how a daring daylight robbery unfolded at the Louvre.

items.summary: Sussan Ley appears increasingly at odds with her party room, following ongoing praise of Australian ambassador Kevin Rudd's performance in Washington.

The Israeli parliament has just narrowly approved a preliminary bill to apply Israeli civil law to the occupied West Bank, a move viewed internationally as a step towards annexation.

Australian-PNG defence treaty: 'one big fence securing two houses'
items.summary: The 31st Australia-Papua New Guinea Ministerial Forum was hosted in Canberra on Monday [[Oct 20]], focusing on the implementation of the historic mutual defence treaty signed between the two countries earlier this month. The 'puk-puk' treaty will see Australia invest millions of dollars in the PNG defence force. A key part of the deal is a taskforce to recruit PNG citizens into the Australian Defence Force, but this has been criticized by former PNG defence personnel who claim the pact is harmful because PNG does not share Australia's fear of China.

items.title: Investor warning about FOMO as gold stocks tumble
items.summary: The gold price has seen its worst one day fall in 12 years as gold stocks tumble after their recent run. Similarly, rare earths also slide. SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Cameron Gleeson from Betashares and Scott Phillips from The Motley Fool to find out why some investors are pressing the sell button and offers a reality check.

items.title: 'They've been great': Trump made a major concession to Australia on defence
items.summary: After previously calling for more investment in defence, it appears Donald Trump has let Australia off the hook.

items.title: Gaza ceasefire going 'better than expected', JD Vance says on Israel trip
items.summary: More than a week into the Gaza ceasefire, senior US officials have visited Israel to discuss ways to progress to the next stage of Donald Trump's 20-point peace plan. Flareups of violence in recent days has threatened to unravel the ceasefire. Meanwhile, the United Nations says it is important the ceasefire holds - to allow for aid deliveries to be scaled up in Gaza.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 22 October 2025
items.summary: A five-minute bulletin for English Language learners

items.title: Battlefields, boardrooms, briefing rooms: Ukraine war drags on after delays in ceasefire talks
items.summary: Diplomacy has overtaken the battlefield in the Ukraine war, with Washington, Moscow, and Kyiv offering starkly different paths to peace. The Kremlin says no Trump-Putin summit date is set, while Washington insists leverage not concessions will end the war.

items.title: PM's plane makes emergency landing in US after crew member hurt
items.summary: Anthony Albanese was returning from his trip to the US, where he met with US President Donald Trump.

items.title: JD Vance says he has 'great optimism' Gaza ceasefire will hold, as more bodies returned
items.summary: There has been tension over the ceasefire, with Hamas saying it needs time to find the remaining bodies of Israeli hostages.

items.title: Breastfeeding reduces the risk of breast cancer, researchers say
items.summary: Australian researchers have found breastfeeding can protect women against breast cancer by building up their immunity. According to a new study, pregnancy and breastfeeding produces infection-fighting T-cells that help guard against abnormal cells that could develop into cancer.

items.title: Windy city: Victorians left without power and NSW heat records smashed in 'extreme' day
items.summary: A heat "bubble" from the outback smashed temperature records across NSW, while damaging and destructive winds left 14,000 Victorians without power.

items.title: 'It's a big job': Ley backtracks on calls for Kevin Rudd to step down as US ambassador
items.summary: Rudd was caught in an awkward exchange with Donald Trump on Tuesday over derogatory comments he wrote in the past about him.

items.title: The cost of living crisis has financially crippled many Australians. But there's an even bigger problem
items.summary: The cost of living crisis continues to affect many Australians. And the impacts are going well beyond people struggling to pay the bills.

items.title: Trump made no mention of them in his ceasefire address. They say violence is ongoing
items.summary: While the world's focus has been on a ceasefire in Gaza, the occupied West Bank remains a flashpoint.

items.title: The $42 billion 'disaster penalty' hitting these Australian homeowners
items.summary: Flood risks have already wiped billions off the value of Australian homes, according to a new report.

items.title: Rare earths deal boosts some mining shares as ASX hits record
items.summary: The Australian sharemarket hit a record high for a second time in a week as the US and Australia strike a rare earths supply deal, but it was BHP that was a real stand out today. SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Catherine Allfrey from Wavestone Capital to find out if the sector is worth the hype and what else is driving investors.

items.title: Deals signed as Trump and Albanese meet; but what are the wider implications?
items.summary: In a historic meeting between Donald Trump and Anthony Albanese, the AUKUS agreement remained unchanged as the two leaders unveiled a multi-billion-dollar critical minerals deal to secure supply chains and reduce reliance on China. The agreement involves major US investment in Australian mining and processing projects, but has sparked criticism over fears it could give the US too much control over Australia’s resources and sovereignty.

items.title: The growing number of Australians adopting this risky travel trend
items.summary: The government places this "expectation" on all Australians travelling overseas, yet a growing number aren't heeding the advice.

items.title: US officials work to preserve Gaza ceasefire
items.summary: Diplomatic efforts have intensified in the Middle East as the United States works to preserve the fragile Gaza ceasefire following a weekend of renewed violence. The truce, part of US President Donald Trump’s multi-phase Gaza plan, was shaken after a Palestinian attack killed two Israeli soldiers, triggering Israeli airstrikes that left dozens dead.

items.title: Australia and China trade accusations after South China Sea flare incident
items.summary: The potential consequences of a flare striking a plane are severe, an expert has said.

items.title: More sunscreens have been recalled. Is yours among them?

items.summary: An awkward moment between Donald Trump and Kevin Rudd failed to derail the US president's first meeting with "friend" Anthony Albanese.

items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese signed a rare earth minerals deal in Washington, stating it goes beyond "just digging things up".

items.title: As an Olympian, I felt embarrassed about my body. Here's how I regained my pride
items.summary: For years, Olympic swimmer Joanna Fargus tried to hide her success as an athlete because she felt ashamed about her weight.

items.title: PM's balancing act ahead of US talks as China's economy expands by 4.8%
items.summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is in the US meeting President Donald Trump but has a delicate balancing act considering how important China is to Australia. SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Shane Oliver from AMP and David Scutt from Forex.com to find out what it means for Australia and the market reaction.

items.title: 'Concerning' or a sign of 'good things'? What Australia's flu record means
items.summary: There's been a 10 per cent increase in flu rates compared to last year, with doctors sounding the alarm over vaccine hesitancy.

items.title: Diwali shines a light on culture for Australian family in Gujarat
items.summary: This week, more than a billion people around the world are celebrating Diwali, the religious festival celebrating the victory of light over darkness. It's an important time for Australia’s South Asian communities. But one family is going a step further, travelling to India for the occasion. SBS caught up with them in Gujarat, on India’s west coast. This story was produced in collaboration with SBS Gujarati Executive Producer Vatsal Patel.

items.title: Two people dead after plane slides off runway and into sea in Hong Kong
items.summary: The aircraft deviated from the north runway and slid into the sea, Hong Kong's Civil Aviation Department said.

items.title: 'How' not 'who' the question after Louvre crown jewels smash and grab
items.summary: French President Emmanuel Macron says everything is being done to catch the people behind a spectacular jewel heist at the Louvre, the latest in a series of museum robberies. After the brazen theft of some of France's crown jewels in broad daylight, staff and union representatives say not enough has been done to guard the objects and people at one of the world's most famous galleries.

items.title: Police union boss likens Melbourne protest to Northern Ireland in the 1970s
items.summary: Premier Jacinta Allan blamed a "very small number" of counter-protesters for the violence and said they deserved to face "serious consequences".

items.summary: The Coalition is planning tax cuts and policy reform in the lead-up to the next election, but details are scarce.

items.title: 'No violence, very professional': What we know about the Louvre jewellery heist
items.summary: Masked robbers broke into the Paris museum using a crane and angle grinders to steal French crown jewels worth tens of millions of dollars.

items.title: Gaza ceasefire to resume after Israeli strikes kill at least 26
items.summary: Israel said it carried out the strikes after an earlier attack killed two of its soldiers, in what is the most serious test yet of the US-brokered truce.

items.title: A rich cultural heritage celebrated in lights: Diwali
items.summary: Diwali is the biggest festival in India and many South Asian countries, marking the victory of good over evil and the triumph of light over darkness. It is celebrated by more than a billion people around the world, including diaspora communities in Australia.

items.title: When is Diwali and what does the festival celebrate?
items.summary: The global festival of lights lasts five days.

items.title: How 'anti-foreign worker sentiment' is snuffing out the dreams of Australians in the US
items.summary: Rapid political change has shattered the dreams of some Australians who were looking to work or study in the US.

items.title: Could your dog be an addict? Scientists think so
items.summary: Does your dog seem to really, really love playing with a certain toy? It may be something more than harmless fun.

items.title: AI 'supercharging' bullying, minister warns, as $10 million tipped into new school plan
items.summary: Artificial intelligence has led to a "terrifying" new type of bullying, the education minister has warned.

items.title: 'Approach with caution': A warning to the public as gold and silver prices skyrocket
items.summary: While the price of gold has kept skyrocketing, prices "can go down and stay down for a very long period of time", an expert warns.

items.title: 'Irreparably broken': Barnaby Joyce to quit Nationals, won't contest seat at next election
items.summary: Reports the firebrand MP plans to defect to One Nation are not yet confirmed, but his options have been kept open.

items.title: Albanese will finally meet Trump. Here’s how it went for other leaders
items.summary: Since Trump's return to the presidency, over 270 days have passed without an official meeting between Albanese and Trump.

items.title: Barking bad: The ruff road to recovery
items.summary: Dogs can become so attached to particular toys that they display behaviour that would be associated with addiction in humans. Researchers say when the dogs were deprived of their toys in the study, they became so fixated on what they'd lost that their blood pressure increased and they ignored everything else.

items.title: Long-lost diary tells a personal story of China's involvement in D-Day
items.summary: A long-lost diary from a Chinese war veteran has been discovered, detailing the participation of China's participation in D-Day. The 80-page diary was discovered in an abandoned Hong Kong flat, and details Lam Ping Yu's brush with death during the world's largest-ever sea, land and air armada on D Day during World War Two.

items.title: How Donald Trump became a hero in Israel
items.summary: The release of Israeli hostages saw Donald Trump hailed as a hero to the Jewish people this week. This is why he's getting all the credit.

items.title: Gold price warning as some traditional buyers tap out at record levels
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Oreana Private Wealth Chief Investment Officer Isaac Poole in Asia, who says some traditional gold buyers are tapping out of the market at current record levels, plus a look at the day's market action.

items.title: The quiet creep that's making Australian banking less 'inclusive and accessible'
items.summary: A decline in face-to-face banking services and cash facilities is harming some Australians more than others, advocates say.

items.title: Fears grow over truce's fragility amid concerns around hostages bodies, aid
items.summary: Israel is pressing Hamas to honour the ceasefire agreement and return the bodies of hostages still held in Gaza. This comes as satellite images show limited aid convoys entering the enclave through Kerem Shalom, while displaced Palestinians in Khan Younis endure worsening living conditions amid shortages of food, fuel, and clean water. With more than 67,900 Palestinians killed since 2023 and uncertainty over Rafah’s reopening, fears are growing that the fragile truce could collapse.

items.title: What this week's surprise unemployment data could mean for your mortgage repayments
items.summary: Australia's jobless rate has hit a near four-year high, raising speculation it could trigger another rate cut by the Reserve Bank.

items.title: Government considering offshore recognition of migrant skills
items.summary: Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke says the government is working on the possibility of an offshore recognition of skills. He says this will help save time and money for skilled migrants looking to move to Australia. In his address the Press Club in Canberra Mr Burke also flagged changes to inactive bank accounts to combat money laundering.

items.title: Australia’s rental affordability 'myth' that doesn’t match reality
items.summary: Workers in critical sectors are frequently locked out of affordable housing — and not just in capital cities, a new report says.

items.title: 'Bombs have stopped, but threats remain': The 'absolute catastrophe' inside Gaza
items.summary: Humanitarian groups call for all Gaza crossings to open so more aid can enter, warning efforts depend on sustaining the fragile ceasefire.

items.title: Melbourne’s weekly pro-Palestinian protests to pause after Gaza ceasefire
items.summary: Organisers say Sunday rallies outside the state library will be halted, a move which was reportedly welcomed by Melbourne's lord mayor.

items.title: Israel delays reopening of crucial Gaza border, rules out aid transfers
items.summary: A key border crossing between Gaza and Egypt will remain closed, dashing hopes it would quickly open under a ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas.

items.title: SPECIAL EPISODE: Inside the Gaza ceasefire: hostages, prisoners & a negotiator
items.summary: Israeli hostages have been released and Palestinians prisoners freed, but is the Trump-brokered truce a turning point or just a timeout? This in-depth episode explores the deal, the delivery of aid, and the future of Gaza.

items.title: The great divide: Australians reach a 'difficult' new high
items.summary: Some say the numbers show life is getting harder, while others argue the picture isn’t as "dire" as it seems.

items.title: ASX hits record as jobless rate rises to 4.5%
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Chris Brycki from Stockspot while Stephanie Youseff talks with Alex Joiner from IFM Investors about the rise in the unemployment rate to a near four year high, what it means for interest rates and why the sharemarket hit a record as a result.

items.title: Germany, NATO pledge billions in new Ukraine aid as Russia reels from fuel strikes
items.summary: Germany and NATO allies have pledged billions in new aid to Ukraine as the war nears its fourth winter, with Kyiv urging urgent air-defence support amid a sharp drop in foreign assistance. Meanwhile, Russia is grappling with fuel shortages following Ukrainian strikes, as President Donald Trump renews his criticism of Vladimir Putin over the prolonged conflict and Russia’s faltering economy.

items.title: Hamas-Israel ceasefire holds - but only just
items.summary: Two more bodies of deceased hostages have been handed over to the Red Cross by Hamas, following Israel's accusation that the militant group were failing to abide by the terms of the ceasefire deal. Aid is continuing to roll into Gaza despite threats from Israel that they would cut supplies and close border crossings. But there are heightened concerns for the fragile ceasefire, amid reports US President Donald Trump is considering allowing Israel to resume its military activities.

items.title: Trump confirms he authorised covert CIA operations in Venezuela
items.summary: Donald Trump said he was "looking at land now" after recently targeting alleged drug smuggling boats from Venezuela by sea.

items.title: Is your job burning you out? Experts say better boundaries and workplace connections can help
items.summary: Despite a growing awareness around mental health, research shows burnout in the workplace is still a major challenge. Experts say without proper training and healthy boundaries in the workplace, more and more Australians will consider leaving their jobs in the next year.

items.title: Madagascar braces for military rule as coup leader prepares to be sworn in
items.summary: The African Union said it was suspending Madagascar after a coup ousted President Andry Rajoelina.

items.title: Madagascar braces for military rule as coup leader prepares to be sworn in
items.summary: The African Union said it was suspending Madagascar after a coup ousted President Andry Rajoelina.

items.title: Australia's rainforests are now adding to carbon emissions, scientists say
items.summary: A new study has found Queensland's tropical rainforests emit more carbon than they absorb, raising concerns for Australia's climate targets.

items.title: The 'confluence of crises' driving Australia's record-low fertility rate
items.summary: Australia's birth rate is declining — but researchers say it's "not about selfishness".

items.title: What record low fertility rates mean for our economy & gold hits another record
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with McCrindle Social Researcher Ashley Fell about thegrowing trend for Australians to have fewer kids, and later in life; plus Luke Laretive from Seneca Financial Services looks through the day's sharemarket moves including what he is telling his clients.
